response.raw:
Here is my attempt at the requested output:

Disseminating Information on BI Tools, Reports, and Metadata

1. Identify the key stakeholders and end users who need to be informed about BI tools, reports, and metadata enhancements. This may include executives, managers, analysts, and other BI consumers across various departments. 2. Develop clear and concise documentation explaining the purpose, features, and benefits of each BI tool, report, or metadata enhancement. Use non-technical language that can be easily understood by a business audience. Include screenshots and examples where appropriate. 3. Schedule training sessions or workshops to walk users through how to access and utilize the BI tools and reports. Provide hands-on exercises so users can practice working with the tools and reports themselves. Record the sessions so they can be accessed later as needed. 4. Set up a centralized repository or knowledge base where all documentation and resources related to the BI tools, reports, and metadata are stored and can be easily accessed by users. Ensure the repository is well-organized and searchable. 5. Send out announcements via email, newsletters, and other corporate communication channels to let users know about the availability of new or enhanced BI tools, reports, and metadata resources. Provide links to the relevant documentation and training materials. 6. Identify power users and champions within each department who can help evangelize the BI tools and reports and provide departmental training and support. Keep them updated on all new developments so they can disseminate the information to their teams.
response.extracted:
Disseminating Information on BI Tools, Reports, and Metadata

1. Identify the key stakeholders and end users who need to be informed about BI tools, reports, and metadata enhancements. This may include executives, managers, analysts, and other BI consumers across various departments. 2. Develop clear and concise documentation explaining the purpose, features, and benefits of each BI tool, report, or metadata enhancement. Use non-technical language that can be easily understood by a business audience. Include screenshots and examples where appropriate. 3. Schedule training sessions or workshops to walk users through how to access and utilize the BI tools and reports. Provide hands-on exercises so users can practice working with the tools and reports themselves. Record the sessions so they can be accessed later as needed. 4. Set up a centralized repository or knowledge base where all documentation and resources related to the BI tools, reports, and metadata are stored and can be easily accessed by users. Ensure the repository is well-organized and searchable. 5. Send out announcements via email, newsletters, and other corporate communication channels to let users know about the availability of new or enhanced BI tools, reports, and metadata resources. Provide links to the relevant documentation and training materials. 6. Identify power users and champions within each department who can help evangelize the BI tools and reports and provide departmental training and support. Keep them updated on all new developments so they can disseminate the information to their teams.
